items.content_html:
The PR adds following features:
a. Detects file deletions and checks if corresponding slugs are being used in rest of the content. Logs the files, line, column, and message.
b. Detects markdown header updates and reports any URL fragments in content that refers the headers.

Above features are enforced in following way:

  1. Husky - executes both the a. and b. features mentioned above during precommit and fails if any cases found.
  2. GitHub PR check - executes feature b.. Tags broken places in content and fails the workflow. Demo PR for this can be found here.

ping @teoli2003
items.title: feat(husky): check deletions and broken fragments in URLs

Description

I was having issues with uploading the req.body to the server and then I realised that body parsing was required and so I've added it into the index route.

Motivation

This change helps confused learners who are unable to tell why req.body is undefined.

items.content_html:
Description

Removes dead link along with the legacy add-ons mention.

Motivation

Link is dead. There is a version saved through Internet Archive that could be used, but legacy Firefox add-ons haven't been supported for a really long time now, so mentioning them in 2023 seems to make little sense anyway.

Additional details

Dead link: https://extensionworkshop.com/documentation/develop/porting-a-legacy-firefox-extension/

Related issues and pull requests

None
items.title: Remove dead tutorial link for porting legacy Firefox add-ons

items.content_html:
Description

It has been agreed that the new syntax for CSS custom states will be :state(foo) rather than :--foo. Chrome has shipped :--foo for a little while now but both Firefox and WebKit implementations support the :state(foo) syntax and Chrome will soon be updated to support both (with some pathway to deprecating the :--foo syntax). Consequently this is an attempt to update the documentation to reflect this, by presenting the core content as using the :state(foo) syntax whilst mentioning that :--foo is the legacy syntax.

Motivation

Both Firefox and WebKit support the new syntax behind a flag and may start shipping this syntax. The HTML spec has a PR (whatwg/html#8467) that defines the new :state(foo) syntax. Chrome will likely update to support both soon.

Currently this support creates a discrepancy between the support the browsers have, intend to have, and what the documentation outlines. The motivation here is to point folks toward the new syntax while also pointing out the legacy issues.

Additional details

whatwg/html#8467
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=266845
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1861466

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: update docs to reflect new css custom state syntax

items.content_html:
Description

I created an advent calendar-themed SVG tutorial. I plan to update it in the future with more interactive examples (integrate this demo for instance), but first I wanted to see if it finds its audience this way.

Is it too soon to link it in the MDN docs? Also, if you have any ideas on how to find its audience, and rank it in Google, or have any feedback, I'd highly appreciate it.

Motivation

I'm working on an interactive SVG tutorial and I'd like to find its audience.

Additional details

items.content_html:
Added the initial content for the index.md file, including information on HTML form attributes.

Description

‚úçÔ∏è Added comprehensive documentation for HTML form attributes in the index.md file, covering key attributes such as action, method, enctype, target, name, autocomplete, and novalidate. The documentation includes usage examples and explanations of each attribute.

Motivation

‚ùì The addition of this documentation aims to enhance the understanding of HTML form attributes for developers and facilitate the creation of well-structured and accessible web forms.

Additional details

üîó This contribution is in response to and resolves issue #404 in the "mdn/mdn" repository.
items.title: Add HTML Form Attribute Documentation

items.content_html:
FF122 adds support to get whether an element's rendering is been skipped due to content-visibility:auto being set. The support is a new property of the Element.checkVisibility() options parameter object named contentVisibilityAuto. There are also two other options opacityProperty and visibilityProperty created as aliases of other existing options in the same bugzilla https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1859852

There are two complications:

  • The CSS that allows content to be skipped is in preview. That means that checkVisibility() will always return the correct value even now (because it will be false if not in preview).
  • The other two properties are not related to the content-visibility features.

So I think these new options are effectively released, but I'm not sure, and I'm in discussion with BCD/engineering.

For now I have put all these options in experimental features associated with the content-visibility:auto information. I would have some of this information here in any case. But I may need to move some of it to release notes depending on how the discussion falls out with BCD team.

Other docs work for this can be tracked in #31107
items.title: FF122 ExprFeatre: Element.checkVisibility() supports options.contentVisibilityAuto

FF122 adds support for the Screen Wake Lock API in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1589554 in Nightly.

As part of the release work, this is a quick subedit for the Screen Wake Lock API docs. Most of it is just layout change. There are a few minor parts where I have added better cross linking.

Related docs work can be tracked in #31112
